Description: Cement or plaster seal from a wine amphora stopper, with a stamped inscription. Plug is missing, but would have been either a ceramic or cork disc. Broken in half and text obscured or missing in places.
Curator's comments: This type of seal appears in the late Republican period in Italy and is adopted in Egypt during the Augustan period, or possibly before (Thomas 2011: Egyptian Type 1 or imported Type 4). Most likely a type 4 stopper with trader or estate owner's name impressed into the seal. Seal material is hard with ceramic and black stone inclusions that would suggest it is made of hydraulic cement. However the plaster/ cement require analysis to distinguish between Italian pozzolanic cement and Egyptian plasters. Whilst this type of stopper was used across the Mediterranean during the late Republican and early Roman periods, this stamp shape is not paralleled in the Western Mediterranean (See Beltran Lloris 1970; Hesnard & Gianfrotta 1989). Rectangular stamps were commonly used in Egypt (Nachtergael 2000), though the point at the end is rare except for two good parallels in the British Museum from Sidmant in the Fayum (BM GR 1910,1012.2) and from Alexandria (BM GR 1883,0430.3, Smith 1883). This type has not yet appeared on the Red Sea coast (Bailey 2007; Bos 2007; Bos & Helms 2000; Bruyère 1966 ; Cashman, Bos, & Pintozzi 1999; Dieleman 1998; Johnson 1979; Moulder 2007; Thomas 2011; Thomas & Tomber 2006).
